(Minister of Interior) |howmany1 = |howmany2 = |casualties1 = |casualties2 = |fatalities = 90{{cite news|title=90 Egyptians killed in week's clashes|url=http://www.worldbulletin.net/?aType=haber&ArticleID=112593|accessdate=6 July 2013|publisher=World Bulletin|date=6 July 2013}} |injuries = 3,000{{cite web|url=http://www.egyptindependent.com/news/health-ministry-52-dead-unrest-began |title=Health Ministry: 52 dead since unrest began |publisher=[[Egypt Independent]] |date= |accessdate=6 July 2013}}{{cite news|title=31 Egyptians killed in clashes|url=http://www.worldbulletin.net/?aType=haber&ArticleID=112531|accessdate=6 July 2013|publisher=World Bulletin|date=6 July 2013}} |notes = }} {{Campaignbox Islamist unrest in Egypt (2013–present)}} {{Egyptian crisis (2011–14)}} The '''2013 Egyptian coup d'état''' took place on 3 July 2013. Egyptian army chief General [[Abdel Fattah el-Sisi]] led a coalition to remove the President of Egypt, [[Mohamed Morsi]], from power and suspended the [[Egyptian Constitution of 2012|Egyptian constitution of 2012]]. The move came after the military's ultimatum for the government to "resolve its differences" with protesters during [[June 2013 Egyptian protests|widespread national protests]]. The military arrested Morsi and [[Muslim Brotherhood]] leaders,{{cite news|title=Coup topples Egypt's Morsy; deposed president under 'house arrest'|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/07/03/world/meast/egypt-protests|first=Ben|last=Wedeman|work=CNN|date=4 July 2013}} and declared Chief Justice of the [[Supreme Constitutional Court (Egypt)]] [[Adly Mansour]] as the interim president of Egypt. The announcement was followed by demonstrations and clashes between supporters and opponents of the move throughout Egypt. The military's action was supported by the [[Grand Imam of al-Azhar|Grand Sheikh of Al Azhar]] [[Ahmed el-Tayeb]], the [[Pope of the Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria|Coptic Orthodox Pope]] [[Pope Tawadros II of Alexandria|Tawadros II]] and opposition leader [[Mohamed ElBaradei]].{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/07/201376165715352978.html|agency=Al Jazeera|title=Elbaradei appointed as Egypt's interim PM|date=6 July 2013|accessdate=6 July 2013}} There were mixed international reactions to the events.[http://blog.chron.com/bakerblog/2013/07/egypt-after-the-revolution-only-the-beginning-of-the-beginning/ Egypt after the coup: Only the beginning of the beginning |Baker Institute Blog |a Chron.com blog]{{dead link|date=July 2016}}. Blog.chron.com (17 July 2013). Retrieved on 14 August 2013. Most Arab leaders were generally supportive or neutral, with the exception of [[Tunisia]] who strongly condemned the military's actions. The US refused to describe the action as a coup. Other states either condemned or expressed concern over the removal of Morsi.{{Cite web|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/07/201373223029610370.html|title=International reactions to Morsi's removal|website=www.aljazeera.com|access-date=2018-11-21}} Due to the regulations of the [[African Union]] regarding the interruption of constitutional rule by a member state, Egypt was suspended from that union. There has also been debate in the media regarding the labeling of these events. It has been described by Western mainstream media as a coup{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/07/05/world/meast/egypt-coup |title=26 dead, more than 850 wounded as post-coup violence hits Egypt |agency=[[CNN]]|date=5 July 2013|accessdate=7 July 2013}}{{cite news|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/2/8/75996/World/Region/Turkey-strongly-condemns-Egypt-killings.aspx|title=Turkey 'strongly condemns' Egypt killings|agency=[[Al Ahram]]|date=7 July 2013|accessdate=7 July 2013}}{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2013/07/05/egypt-coup-violence/2493373/|title=Amid post-coup clashes, Egypt's Islamists split|agency=[[USA Today]]|date=5 July 2013|accessdate=7 July 2013|first1=Oren|last1=Dorell}}{{cite news|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/turkeys-stance-on-egypt-coup-shows-its-democratic-maturity.aspx?pageID=238&nID=50210&NewsCatID=338|title=Turkey's stance on Egypt coup ‘shows its democratic maturity’|agency=Hurriyet Daily News|date=7 July 2013|accessdate=7 July 2013}}{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/comment/when-is-a-military-coup-not-a-military-coup-when-it-happens-in-egypt-apparently-8688000.html|title=When is a military coup not a military coup? When it happens in Egypt, apparently|agency=[[The Independent]]|date=4 July 2013|accessdate=15 July 2013|location=London|first=Robert|last=Fisk}} or as a [[revolution]]{{refn|See {{cite news|url=http://www.dw.de/revolution-in-egypt-again/a-16928333|title=Revolution in Egypt, again|agency=[[Deutsche Welle]]|date=4 July 2013|accessdate=6 July 2013}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jul/03/mohamed-morsi-egypt-second-revolution|title=Mohamed Morsi ousted in Egypt's second revolution in two years|agency=The Guardian|date=3 July 2013|accessdate=6 July 2013|location=London|first1=Patrick|last1=Kingsley|first2=Martin|last2=Chulov}}{{cite news|url=http://www.newsmax.com/Newsfront/ahmed-said-egypt-revolution/2013/07/05/id/513575|agency=[[Newsmax]]|title=Ahmed Said to Newsmax: Egyptian Uprising 'Big Revolution'|date=5 July 2013|accessdate=6 July 2013}}{{cite news|url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2013/07/was-morsi-ouster-a-coup-or-new-egyptian-revolution.html|title=Was Morsi's Ouster a Coup Or New Egyptian Revolution?|publisher=[[Al Monitor]]|date=4 July 2013|accessdate=6 July 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130719121519/http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2013/07/was-morsi-ouster-a-coup-or-new-egyptian-revolution.html|archive-date=19 July 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}}} by proponents. Ensuing protests in favour of Morsi were violently suppressed culminating with the [[August 2013 Rabaa massacre|dispersal and massacre of pro-Morsi sit-ins]] on 14 August 2013, amid [[Post-coup unrest in Egypt (2013–14)|ongoing unrest]]; journalists,{{cite news|title=In Egypt, two more journalists killed, several injured |publisher=Committee to Protect Journalists |date=15 August 2013 |accessdate=17 August 2013 |url=http://www.cpj.org/2013/08/in-egypt-two-more-journalists-killed-several-injur.php |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6J0c7dkLt?url=http://www.cpj.org/2013/08/in-egypt-two-more-journalists-killed-several-injur.php |archivedate=20 August 2013 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} and several hundreds protestors were killed by police and military force. Muslim brotherhood members claim 2,600 {{Cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/08/201381522364486906.html |title=Egypt's Brotherhood to hold 'march of anger' |work=Al Jazeera |date=16 August 2013 |accessdate=18 August 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Iz4rEMPW?url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/08/201381522364486906.html |archivedate=19 August 2013 |quote=Muslim Brotherhood members have said the true death toll was far higher, with a spokesperson saying 2,600 people had been killed in the "massacre". |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} Human rights watch documented 817 deaths, calling it ';one of the world's largest killings of demonstrators in a single day in recent history;', while the government puts the figure at 624.{{Cite news|url=https://www.hrw.org/report/2014/08/12/all-according-plan/raba-massacre-and-mass-killings-protesters-egypt|title=All According to Plan|date=2014-08-12|newspaper=Human Rights Watch|access-date=2016-11-15}} ==Background== {{Further information|2011 Egyptian revolution|Aftermath of the 2011 Egyptian revolution|2012–13 Egyptian protests|June 2013 Egyptian protests}} [[File:Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel meets with Egyptian President Mohamed Morsy in Cairo, Egypt, April 24, 2013.jpg|thumb|right|[[Mohamed Morsi|Then President Mohamed Morsi]] (right) and [[Abdel Fattah el-Sisi|General al-Sisi]] (left) listen to visiting U.S. Secretary of Defense [[Chuck Hagel]] (center), during a meeting with U.S. officials on 24 April 2013. Al-Sisi, chosen by Morsi to be the first post-[[Hosni Mubarak|Mubarak]] era Defense Minister,{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-19256730|title=Profile: Egypt armed forces chief Abdul Fattah al-Sisi|publisher=BBC News|date=3 July 2013|accessdate=5 July 2013}} would later sanction the removal of Morsi from office.]] In February 2011, [[Hosni Mubarak]] resigned after [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011|18 days of mass demonstrations]] that ended [[History of Egypt under Hosni Mubarak|his 29-year rule of Egypt]]. In July 2011 the caretaker government approved an election law, leading to election of a Parliament in December 2011 – January 2012, and an advisory council in January–February 2012 [ref: Egyptian Parliamentary Election 2011–2012; Wikipedia] An alliance led by the Freedom and Justice Party won the most seats in each election. An additional 25% of the members of the advisory council were to be appointed by the President. In June 2012, Mohamed Morsi won the [[Egyptian presidential election, 2012|presidential election]] with 51.73% of total votes to become the first democratically elected president of Egypt.{{cite news|last=Khalil |first=Ashraf |url=http://world.time.com/2013/07/03/egypts-military-ousts-democratically-elected-president-morsi-angering-his-islamist-supporters/ |title=Egypt: President Morsi's Ouster Angers Islamist Supporters |publisher=World.time.com |date=30 June 2013 |accessdate=6 July 2013}}{{cite web|last=Lederman |first=Josh |url=http://www.edmontonjournal.com/news/Pentagon+Secretary+Hagel+calls+Egyptian+defence+minister/8611323/story.html |title=Egypt's future uncertain, US takes cautious approach and urges quick return to elected govt |publisher=Edmontonjournal.com |date=2 July 2013 |accessdate=6 July 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131006074344/http://www.edmontonjournal.com/news/Pentagon%2BSecretary%2BHagel%2Bcalls%2BEgyptian%2Bdefence%2Bminister/8611323/story.html |archivedate=6 October 2013 |df=dmy }} In June 2012, prior to Morsi being sworn in as President, the Supreme Constitutional Court ruled that the election law was unconstitutional and ordered the elected bodies dissolved. After assuming office, President Morsi appointed additional members to the advisory council from 35 political parties and invited the elected bodies to meet to discuss the ruling of the court. The elected parliament determined that the constitutional court did not have authority to dissolve an elected parliament, then referred the matter to the Court of Cassation. The elected parliament could not pass any laws, but the advisory council continued to give advice on proposed Presidential Decrees. Parliament also proceeded with creation of a new constitutional committee to draft amendments to the Egyptian Constitution, replacing the committee created in March 2012 but dissolved by the constitutional court. Proposed constitutional amendments were approved in December 2012 by a national referendum.[[Egyptian constitutional referendum, 2012|Egyptian constitutional referendum, 2012 – Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia]] New elections were scheduled for April 2013 under a law approved in draft by the constitutional court, but were postponed to October 2013 to comply with a technical order of an administrative court.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/04/11/us-egypt-elections-law-idUSBRE93A0J720130411 |work=Reuters |title=Egyptian parliament approves revamped election law |date=11 April 2013}}{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2013/04/21/state-agency-representing-egypt-president-loses-appeal-high-court-upholds/ |work=Fox News |title=State agency representing Egypt president loses appeal, high court upholds election suspension |date=21 April 2013}} In November 2012, following the protests against the [[Muslim Brotherhood in post-Mubarak electoral politics of Egypt#President Morsi's temporary assumption of full constitutional power and push for new constitution|Constitutional Declaration]] by Morsi, opposition politicians – including [[Mohamed ElBaradei]], [[Amr Moussa]] and [[Hamdeen Sabahi]], according to the [[The Wall Street Journal|Wall Street Journal]] – started holding confidential meetings with army leaders, in order to discuss ways of removing President Morsi.{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324425204578601700051224658|title=In Egypt, the 'Deep State' Rises Again|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|date=12 July 2013|accessdate=15 July 2013|first1=Charles|last1=Levinson|first2=Matt|last2=Bradley}} On 28 April 2013, [[Tamarod]] was started as a grassroots movement to collect signatures to remove Morsi by 30 June. They called for peaceful demonstrations across Egypt especially in front of the Presidential Palace in Cairo.{{Cite news|title=Egypt's 'Rebel' campaign gathered 22 mn signatures, says spokesman|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/75244/Egypt/Politics-/Egypts-Rebel-campaign-gathered--mn-signatures,-say.aspx|agency=Ahram Online|date=29 June 2013|accessdate=29 June 2013}} The movement was supported by the [[National Salvation Front (Egypt)|National Salvation Front]], [[April 6 Youth Movement]] and [[Strong Egypt Party]].{{Cite news|title=Reactions vary to the Rebel movement's 30 June plans|url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2013/06/05/reactions-vary-to-tamarods-30-june-plans/|agency=Daily News Egypt|date=5 June 2013|accessdate=13 June 2013}}{{Cite news|title=Strong Egypt Party supports protest on 30 June, opposes military coup|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/74273/Egypt/Politics-/Strong-Egypt-Party-supports-protest-on--June,-oppo.aspx|agency=Ahram Online|date=18 June 2013|accessdate=18 June 2013}} In a poll published by PEW research center in May 2013, 54% of Egyptians approved of Morsi against a 43% who saw him negatively, while about 30% were happy with the direction of the country, 73% thought positively of the army and only 35% were content about local policy authorities.{{cite web|url=http://www.pewglobal.org/2013/05/16/egyptians-increasingly-glum/|title=Egyptians Increasingly Glum|date=16 May 2013|work=Pew Research Center's Global Attitudes Project|accessdate=27 April 2016}} In the lead up to the protests, a [[The Gallup Organization|Gallup]] poll indicated that about a third of Egyptians said they were "suffering" and viewed their lives poorly.{{cite web|url=http://www.gallup.com/poll/163877/morsi-ousted-suffering-shot-egypt.aspx |title=As Morsi Ousted, "Suffering" Shot Up in Egypt |publisher=Gallup.com |date= |accessdate=27 September 2013}} At a conference on 15 June, Morsi called for [[Foreign involvement in the Syrian civil war|foreign intervention in Syria]].{{Cite news |title=Egyptian president cuts ties with Syria and calls for no-fly zone over country |agency=Reuters |newspaper=The Guardian |date=15 June 2013 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/15/egypt-mohamed-morsi-cuts-ties-with-syria |location=London}} According to Yasser El-Shimy, an analyst with the [[International Crisis Group]], this statement crossed "a national security red line." The army rebuked this statement the next day by stating that its only role was to guard Egypt's borders. Although the [[Egyptian constitution]] ostensibly declares the president as the supreme commander of the armed forces, the Egyptian military is independent of civilian control.{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/egypt-army-says-morsi-role-at-syria-rally-seen-as-turning-point/1693911.html|title=Morsi role at Syria rally seen as tipping point for Egypt army |work=Reuters|date=2 July 2013 |accessdate=21 January 2014}} As the first anniversary of Morsi's presidential inauguration approached in 2013, his supporters such as the [[Anti-Coup Alliance|National Coalition for Supporting Legitimacy]] started demonstrations at multiple places including [[El-Hossari Mosque]], [[El-Nahda Square]], outside [[Cairo University]], outside Al-Rayan Mosque in the posh suburb of Maadi, and in [[Ain Shams]] district. They had started open-ended rallies.{{cite web |url=http://www.focac.org/eng/zjfz/fzsz/t1054696.htm |title=17 gunmen arrested before reaching pro-Morsi protest in Egypt |publisher=Focac.org |accessdate=3 July 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230235407/http://www.focac.org/eng/zjfz/fzsz/t1054696.htm# |archive-date=30 December 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} The largest protest was planned for 30 June.{{cite web|url=http://www.humanevents.com/2013/07/03/pro-morsi-terrorists-threaten-christians-against-protesting/ |title=Pro-Morsi Terrorists Threaten Christians against Protesting |publisher=Humanevents.com |accessdate=3 July 2013}} ==Causes== The removal of Morsi from office by the coalition was a result of a [[coup d'état]] following protests, that were instigated by frustration with Morsi's year-long rule in which Egypt faced economic issues, energy shortages, lack of security, and diplomatic crises.{{cite web|url=http://masroregypt.wordpress.com/2013/08/16/the-revolution-continues/|title=The Revolution Continues|work=Masr or Egypt|accessdate=27 April 2016}} Some of the issues that might have caused the protests and lead to the later removal of Morsi include: * A year earlier (on 22 November 2012), President Morsi enacted a constitutional declaration, granting the presidential power to appoint the People's Prosecutor, and until the constitution was finalized, and a new People's Assembly was elected, all Presidential decisions were final and irrefutable. The declaration also immunized the Constituent Assembly and Shura Council from dissolution.{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/58947.aspx |title=English text of Morsi's Constitutional Declaration – Politics – Egypt – Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=27 September 2013}} The declaration was later abrogated before referendum due to multiple protests and public anger.{{cite news|last=Spencer|first=Richard|title=Violence breaks out across Egypt as protesters decry Mohammed Morsi's constitutional 'coup'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/9699801/Violence-breaks-out-across-Egypt-as-protesters-decry-Mohammed-Morsis-constitutional-coup.html|newspaper=Telegraph|date=23 November 2012|location=London}}{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/50248.aspx |title=English text of President Morsi's new Egypt Constitutional Declaration – First 100 days – Egypt – Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=27 September 2013}} {{Verify source|date=April 2016}} * [[Muslim Brotherhood]] and their [[Freedom and Justice Party (Egypt)|ruling political party]] using the majority of their members and allies in the constitutional committee to pass a hotly disputed constitution. Even approved by 64% of Egyptians who voted, it was noted only about 30% of Egyptians with voting rights participated in the referendum process.{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/0/61118/Egypt/0/Egyptians-approve-first-postuprising-constitution.aspx|title=Egyptians approve first post-uprising constitution|publisher=|accessdate=27 April 2016}}{{cite news|author=|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-202_162-57556779/anti-morsi-protests-threaten-to-go-even-wider/ |title=Anti-Morsi protests threaten to go even wider |publisher=CBS News |date=3 December 2012 |accessdate=27 September 2013}} which caused secular and liberal party members and church representatives to withdraw from the committee.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2012/11/24/all-civilian-parties-withdraw-from-constitutional-assembly/ |title=Non-Islamist members withdraw from Constitutional Assembly |publisher=Daily News Egypt |date= |accessdate=27 September 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.egyptindependent.com/news/egyptian-churches-withdraw-constituent-assembly |title=Egyptian churches withdraw from Constituent Assembly |publisher=Egypt Independent |date=17 November 2012 |accessdate=27 September 2013}}{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/10/08/us-egypt-constitution-idUSBRE8970RA20121008 |title=U.S.-based rights group says draft Egypt constitution flawed |publisher=Reuters |date= 8 October 2012|accessdate=27 September 2013}} * Power, gas and economical crises.{{cite web|last=Saleh |first=Heba |url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/82ae9418-c857-11e2-8cb7-00144feab7de.html#axzz2deoxOZb8 |title=Egypt's power crisis worsened by declining natural gas production |publisher=FT.com |date=29 May 2013 |accessdate=27 September 2013}}{{cite news|title=Short of Money, Egypt Sees Crisis on Fuel and Food|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/31/world/middleeast/egypt-short-of-money-sees-crisis-on-food-and-gas.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|newspaper=New York Times|date=30 March 2013|first=David D.|last=Kirkpatrick}}{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2013/03/11/diesel-fuel-crisis-adds-to-egypt-cocktail-political-economic-woes/ |title=Diesel fuel crisis adds to Egypt's cocktail of political, economic woes |publisher=Fox News |date=11 March 2013 |accessdate=27 September 2013}} Plans to cut subsidies in exchange for a $4.8 billion IMF loan which would cause an increase in the price of gas, electricity, food and taxes.{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2013/04/24/egypt-subsidies-idUKL6N0DB2MH20130424 |title=Egypt to issue schedule next month for gradual fuel subsidy cuts | Reuters |publisher=Uk.reuters.com |date=24 April 2013 |accessdate=27 September 2013}} * Several diplomatic problems including construction of Ethiopian dam along the Nile river, affecting Egypt's share of water.{{cite web|author=" + hours + ':' + min + " " + time + " |url=http://carnegieendowment.org/2013/01/17/egypt-uae-diplomatic-crisis/f2qj |title=The Egypt-UAE Diplomatic Crisis – Carnegie Endowment for International Peace |publisher=Carnegieendowment.org |date= |accessdate=27 September 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://oilprice.com/Latest-Energy-News/World-News/Ethiopia-Ignores-Egypts-Empty-Threats-and-Continues-with-Construction-of-Dam.html |title=Ethiopia Ignores Egypt's Empty Threats and Continues with Construction of Dam |publisher=Oilprice.com |date= |accessdate=27 September 2013}} * Security of the state worsened; two of the most prominent stories related to security under Morsi were: the murder of 16 border guards in Sinai in an attack and the abduction of 7 Egyptian security personnel who were later released.{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/49660/Egypt/Politics-/UPDATE---Egyptian-soldiers-killed-at-the-Israel-bo.aspx |title=16 Egyptian soldiers killed at Israel border – Politics – Egypt – Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date=5 August 2012 |accessdate=27 September 2013}}[http://presstv.com/detail/2013/05/22/304778/7-abducted-egyptian-officers-released/ PressTV – Abducted Egyptian security forces released] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130914005112/http://presstv.com/detail/2013/05/22/304778/7-abducted-egyptian-officers-released/ |date=14 September 2013 }} * [[Egyptian Army]] economic interests.{{Cite episode |title= التفاصيل الأخيرة لحكم مرسي |episodelink= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=60ByKuFtH7w |accessdate= 21 December 2013 |series= [[Bela Hodod]] |serieslink= |first= |last= |network= [[Al Jazeera]] |station= |city= |date=18 December 2013 |began= |ended= |season= |seriesno= |number= |minutes= 50 |time= |transcript= |transcripturl= |quote= |language= Arabic}}{{cite web|url=https://translate.google.com/translate?sl=ar&tl=en&js=n&prev=_t&hl=en&ie=UTF-8&u=http%3A%2F%2Frassd.com%2F7-78603.htm |title=Yahya Hamid .. Reveals the secrets of the palace |publisher= [[Rassd News Network (RNN)|RNN]]|date=21 December 2013 |accessdate=28 December 2013}} These include local civil industry, army foreign partnerships related to maritime and air transport, oil and gas and industrial-scale environmental projects such as wastewater treatment and energy generation. Modern economy have always threatened the military economic position.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2012/02/2012215195912519142.html|title=Egypt military's economic empire |publisher=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=15 February 2012 |accessdate=28 December 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/politics/2013/07/egypt-army-economic-interests-coup-morsi.html|title=Egyptian Army Considered Economic Stakes in Coup |publisher=[[Al-Monitor]]|date=6 July 2013 |accessdate=28 December 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://usat.ly/13roA1H|title=Egypt military fights for macaroni, as well as security |publisher=[[USA TODAY]]|date=17 August 2013 |accessdate=28 December 2013}} * On 1 March 2015 Pro-Muslim brotherhood TV Channel in Turkey released audio recording of senior Egyptian officials which suggested that when Mohamed Morsi was president, [[United Arab Emirates]] gave money to Egyptian defense ministry for protest campaign against Morsi, Some money was also transferred to [[Tamarod]].{{cite news|title=Recordings Suggest Emirates and Egyptian Military Pushed Ousting of Morsi|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/02/world/middleeast/recordings-suggest-emirates-and-egyptian-military-pushed-ousting-of-morsi.html?_r=0|accessdate=28 May 2015|publisher=nytimes|date=1 March 2015|first=David D.|last=Kirkpatrick}}{{cite news|title=Audio forensics experts authenticate Sisi's voice on leaked tapes |url=http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/acoustic-experts-authenticate-sisis-voice-leaked-tapes-591410379|accessdate=28 May 2015|publisher=middleeasteye|date=9 May 2015}} ==Planning== Leaked tapes from the summer of 2013 that were later verified by J. P. French Associates {{cite news |last1=Kirkpatrick |first1=Davud |title=Leaks Gain Credibility and Potential to Embarrass Egypt’s Leaders |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/13/world/middleeast/leaks-gain-credibility-and-potential-to-embarrass-egypts-leaders.html |accessdate=19 June 2018 |language=en}} recorded figures of the Egyptian military, including then-Gen. Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, suggesting Egyptian military involvement in the mass-protests preceding Morsi's ouster.{{cite news|last1=Kirkpatrick|first1=David|title=Recordings Suggest Emirates and Egyptian Military Pushed Ousting of Morsi|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/02/world/middleeast/recordings-suggest-emirates-and-egyptian-military-pushed-ousting-of-morsi.html?_r=0|accessdate=8 October 2015|publisher=The New York Times|date=1 March 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2015/05/10/secret-tapes-of-the-2013-egypt-coup-plot-pose-a-problem-for-obama.html|title=Secret Tapes of the 2013 Egypt Coup Plot Pose a Problem for Obama|publisher=The Daily Beast|date=10 May 2015|accessdate=16 May 2015}} In one of the leaked tapes, the generals are heard discussing rigging the legal case against Morsi, and in another, authorizing the withdrawal of a large sum of money for the army's use from the bank account of [[Tamarod]], the ostensibly independent grassroots group that was organizing protests against President Morsi. The tapes also suggest high-level collusion between the coup plotters and the [[Politics of the United Arab Emirates|Government of the United Arab Emirates]] as the money that is to be transferred from Tamarod's account into the army's account was provided by the [[United Arab Emirates|UAE]]. The tapes were first released on the Turkish Islamist channel ''Mekameleen'', a fact that the Egyptian government says discredits the tapes as fakes. American officials later confirmed that the United Arab Emirates was indeed providing financial support for the protests against Morsi that preceded the military coup.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/27/sunday-review/obama-egypt-coup-trump.html?|title=The White House and the Strongman|access-date=2018-11-21|language=en}} ==Events== {{main article|June 2013 Egyptian protests}} [[File:Anti Morsi protest march at 28th June 2013.jpg|thumb|Anti-Morsi demonstrators marching in Cairo on 28 June]] On Friday 28 June, protests against Morsi started to build throughout Egypt including in such cities as [[Cairo]], [[Alexandria]], [[Dakahlia Governorate|Dakahlia]], [[Gharbia Governorate|Gharbiya]] and [[Aswan]] as a "warm up" for the massive protests expected on 30 June that were planned by Tamarod. Pro-Morsi and Muslim Brotherhood supporters started counter demonstrations at the [[Rabia Al-Adawiya Mosque]] in Nasr City.{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/75483.aspx |title=Egypt warms up for a decisive day of anti- and pro-Morsi protests |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date=7 February 2013 |accessdate=3 July 2013}} Prior to the protests, Christians, particularly in Upper Egypt, received threats from pro-Morsi protestors, pressuring them not to take part in the protests. Sheikh Essam Abdulamek, a member of parliament's Shura Council, said in an interview on television that Christians should not participate in the protests and warned them "do not sacrifice your children [since the] general Muslim opinion will not be silent about the ousting of the president." According to information that came out after the removal of Morsi, officials claimed that Morsi stopped working at [[Egyptian Presidential Palace]] on 26 June in anticipation to the protests and moved with his family to [[El-Quba Palace]].{{cite web|last=Hendawi |first=Hamza |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/his-final-days-morsi-was-isolated-defiant |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130707111210/http://bigstory.ap.org/article/his-final-days-morsi-was-isolated-defiant |archivedate=7 July 2013 |title=In his final days, Morsi was isolated but defiant |publisher=Bigstory.ap.org |date=1 July 2013 |dead-url=yes |accessdate=6 July 2013 }} On 29 June, Tamarod claimed that it collected more than 22 million signatures from a petition calling for Morsi to step down as president.{{cite news|title=Tahrir Square protesters show President Mursi the ‘red card’|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2013/06/30/Egypt-braces-for-June-30-rebellion-as-Mursi-marks-first-year-.html|accessdate=1 July 2013|publisher=[[Al Arabiya]]|date=30 June 2013}}{{cite news|title=Profile: Egypt's Tamarod protest movement|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-23131953|accessdate=1 July 2013|publisher=BBC News|date=1 July 2013}} On the other hand, the coup was preceded by the reconciliation of military and economic elites who organized shortages of fuel to provoke discontent of general population toward the Morsi administration.[https://www.academia.edu/25995601/Egyptian_coup_of_2013_an_econometric_analysis Egyptian coup of 2013: an ‘econometric’ analysis. ''The Journal of North African Studies''. 2016. Vol. 21 (3). P. 341–356]. DOI: 10.1080/13629387.2015.1124238 ===30 June: Anti-Morsi demonstrations=== On 30 June, according to unverified military sources, 14 million protesters demonstrated across Egypt against Morsi bellowing their anger at the Brotherhood, which they accuse of hijacking Egypt's revolution and using electoral victories to monopolize power and impose Islamic law.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/06/30/us-egypt-protests-idUSBRE95Q0NO20130630 |work=Reuters |first=Asma |last=Alsharif |title=Millions flood Egypt's streets to demand Mursi quit |date=30 June 2013}} Thousands in support of Morsi gathered in Rabaa Square in Cairo and other cities, with majority of Islamist sentiments.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/01/world/middleeast/egypt.html?pagewanted=all |work=The New York Times |first1=David D. |last1=Kirkpatrick |first2=Kareem |last2=Fahim |first3=Ben |last3=Hubbard |title=By the Millions, Egyptians Seek Morsi's Ouster |date=30 June 2013}} The Egyptian Armed Forces claimed the number to be at 14 million and reportedly one of the biggest protests in world history.{{cite web|url=http://www.theatlanticwire.com/global/2013/06/heres-what-todays-massive-anti-morsi-protests-egypt-looked/66728/ |title=What Sunday's Massive Anti-Morsi Protests in Egypt Looked Like – Abby Ohlheiser |publisher=The Atlantic Wire |accessdate=3 July 2013}} In [[Damietta]], 250 fishing boat sailors demonstrated against Morsi by sailing through the Nile and chanting against him.{{cite news|title=250 fishing boats sail in Damietta, protest Morsy|url=http://www.egyptindependent.com/news/250-fishing-boats-sail-damietta-protest-morsy|accessdate=7 July 2013|newspaper=Egypt Independent|date=30 June 2013}} The President moved that day from the Quba Palace to the Republican Guard headquarters, while protesters thought he was at Ittihadeya Palace. ===1 July: Deadlines and Options=== {{External media|video1 = [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vxhcDzoCe9g Helicopter view of the protesters]|align = right}} On 1 July, again more than 1 millions of demonstrators against Morsi gathered in [[Tahrir Square]] and outside the [[Heliopolis Palace|presidential palace]], while other demonstrations were held in the cities of Alexandria, [[Port Said]] and [[Suez]].{{cite news|title=Egypt crisis: Mass protests over Morsi grip cities|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-23115821|accessdate=1 July 2013|publisher=BBC News|date=1 July 2013}} Some police officers wearing their uniforms joined the anti-Morsi protests and chanted: "The police and the people are one."{{cite news|title=Egypt on the edge: Troops seen preparing for unarmed combat after President Morsi rebuffs army 48-hour deadline|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/egypt-on-the-edge-troops-seen-preparing-for-unarmed-combat-after-president-morsi-rebuffs-army-48hour-coup-deadline-8681882.html|newspaper=The Independent|date=1 July 2013|location=London|first1=Alastair|last1=Beach|first2=Heather|last2=Saul}} In clashes around the Muslim Brotherhood headquarters in [[Mokatam]], eight people died. Their headquarters was ransacked and burned while protesters threw objects at windows and looted the building, making off with office equipment and documents.{{cite news|title=Egypt protesters storm Muslim Brotherhood headquarters|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-23125387|accessdate=1 July 2013|publisher=BBC News|date=1 July 2013}} Tamarod gave President Mohamed Morsi until 2 July at 17:00 to resign or face a civil disobedience campaign. That was followed by the [[Egyptian Armed Forces]] issuing a 48-hour ultimatum that gave the country's political parties until 3 July to meet the demands of the Egyptian people. The Egyptian military also threatened to intervene if the dispute was not resolved by then.{{cite news|last=Abdelaziz|first=Salma|title=Egyptian military issues warning over protests|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/07/01/world/meast/egypt-protests/index.html?hpt=hp_t1|accessdate=1 July 2013|publisher=CNN|date=1 July 2013}} Four ministers also resigned on the same day: [[Ministry of Tourism (Egypt)|Tourism Minister]] [[Hisham Zazou]] (who previously offered to resign a few months earlier after Morsi appointed an Islamist member of [[al-Gama'a al-Islamiyya]], the group allegedly responsible of the [[Luxor massacre]], though the group has denied this charge, as governor of [[Luxor]]), [[Ministry of Communications and Information Technology (Egypt)|Communication and IT Minister]] [[Atef Helmi]], State Minister for Legal and Parliamentary Affairs [[Hatem Bagato]], and State Minister for Environmental Affairs [[Khaled Abdel Aal]],{{Cite news|author=Patrick Werr|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/07/01/us-egypt-protests-ministers-idUSBRE9600IE20130701|accessdate=1 July 2013|title=Four Egyptian ministers resign after protests: cabinet official|agency=Reuters|date=1 July 2013}} leaving the government with only members of the [[Freedom and Justice Party (Egypt)|Freedom and Justice Party]]. On the same day, it was reported that [[Barack Obama]] called Morsi. The call went along the [[United States]] vision and that the only one option out of the stressed situation would be to call for an early general presidential election in which Morsi is not a candidate. The proposition which Morsi answered: "the Egyptian people decide", before he closed the line. ===2 July: Morsi speech=== On 2 July, opponents and supporters of Morsi gathered in the capital, Cairo, as the deadline set by the military for him to solve the escalating political problem where they said they would intervene without the elimination of either sides, however, they betrayed their speech and the president and engineered a coup the next day.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-23142387|title=Four Egypt rivals take to streets ahead of Morsi deadline|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=16 March 2014|date=2 July 2013}} Helicopters were also present around Cairo with armored vehicles taking up positions. On 3 July, clashes between protestors and local residents erupted around a pro-Morsi rally near Cairo University, leaving 18 people dead.{{Cite news|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2013/07/05/egypt-deadly-clashes-cairo-university|title=Egypt: Deadly Clashes at Cairo University}} [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Egypt)|Foreign Minister]] [[Mohamed Kamel Amr]] also resigned, in support of the anti-government protesters.{{cite news|title=FM becomes fifth cabinet official to resign|url=http://www.egyptindependent.com/news/fm-becomes-fifth-cabinet-official-resign|accessdate=2 July 2013|newspaper=[[Egypt Independent]]|date=2 July 2013}} The presidency rejected the [[Egyptian Army]]'s 48-hour ultimatum, vowing that the president would pursue his own plans for national reconciliation to resolve the political crisis.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-23140212|accessdate=2 July 2013|title=Egypt crisis: President Morsi rejects army ultimatum|publisher=BBC News|date=2 July 2013}} [[List of Ministers of Defence of Egypt|Defense Minister]] General [[Abdel Fattah el-Sisi]] was also said to have told Morsi that he would impose a military solution if a political one could not be found by the next day.{{cite news|last=Shahine |first=Alaa |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-07-02/mursi-trust-in-military-man-s-loyalty-backfires-as-egypt-teeters.html |title=Mursi Trust in Army's Man Loyalty Backfires as Egypt Teeters |publisher=Bloomberg L.P. |accessdate=3 July 2013}} Incidentally, the [[Court of Cassation (Egypt)|Court of Cassation]] ordered the reinstatement of former general prosecutor [[Abdel Meguid Mahmoud|Abdel Maguid Mahmoud]] who was replaced with [[Talaat Abdallah]] following the constitutional declaration on 22 November 2012.{{cite news|title=Court orders return of Meguid Mahmoud as prosecutor general|url=http://www.egyptindependent.com/news/court-orders-return-meguid-mahmoud-prosecutor-general|accessdate=2 July 2013|newspaper=[[Egypt Independent]]|date=2 July 2013}} The presidential spokesman and the spokesman for the cabinet resigned as well.{{cite news|url = http://www.egyptindependent.com/news/latest-wave-resignations-cabinet-presidency-spokesmen-quit|date = 2 July 2013|title = Latest wave of resignations as Cabinet, Presidency spokesmen quit |publisher = Egypt Independent}} The newspaper ''[[Al-Ahram]]'' reported that if there were no political resolution, the military would suspend the [[constitution of Egypt]] and appoint a new council of experts to draft a new one, institute a three-person executive council, and appoint a prime minister from the military.{{cite news|last=Kirkpatrick|first=David D.|title=Morsi Defies Egypt Army's Ultimatum to Bend to Protest|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/03/world/middleeast/egypt-protests.html|accessdate=3 July 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=2 July 2013|author2=Hubbard, Ben}} Morsi's military advisor, [[Sami Hafez Anan]], also resigned and said that the army would not "abandon the will of the people."{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/07/20137215593626253.html |title=Morsi tells Egypt army to withdraw ultimatum |publisher=Al Jazeera |accessdate=3 July 2013}} In a late-night television address Morsi declared that he would "defend the legitimacy of his elected office with his life."{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-23154233|title=Egypt's Mohammed Morsi vows to stay in office|date=3 July 2013|publisher=BBC News}} He added that "there is no substitute for legitimacy" as he vowed not to resign.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/07/20137222343142718.html |title=Egypt's Morsi says he will not step down |publisher=Al Jazeera |accessdate=3 July 2013}} Morsi accused supporters of Hosni Mubarak of exploiting the wave of protests to topple the government and fight democracy.{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/breaking-news/egypt-protesters-mass-after-morsi-snub/story-fn3dxix6-1226673461184 |title=Egypt military chiefs hold crisis talks |work=The Australian |date=3 July 2013 |accessdate=6 July 2013}} After Morsi's statement, an official Facebook page of the [[Egyptian Armed Forces]] wrote a post under the title "The Last Hours" saying in response to Morsi: "The Supreme Commander in Chief of the [[Egyptian Armed Forces]] had mentioned before that it's better for us to die rather than seeing the Egyptian People being threatened or horrified, and we swear that we would sacrifice our lives and our blood for Egypt against every terrorist or extremist or ignorant. Long live Egypt."{{cite web|title=The Last Hours|url=https://www.facebook.com/Egyptian.Armed.Forces.Admins/posts/633415760005031}}{{cite news|title=Egypt's President Mohammed Morsi, Army Chiefs Prepare For Showdown Hours Ahead of Ultimatum|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/07/03/egypt-president-morsi-army-showdown_n_3539548.html?ref=topbar|work=Huffington Post|accessdate=16 March 2014|first=Eline|last=Gordts|date=3 July 2013}} ===3 July: Day of Action=== [[File:General Al Sisi.jpg|thumb|right|General [[Abdul Fatah al-Sisi]] in 2013.]] As the deadline of the army's ultimatum approached on 3 July, there was renewed expectation of an increase in violence, according to the media.{{cite web|author=Dahlia Kholaif |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2013/07/201373104310728444.html |title=Fears of bloodshed loom large in Egypt |publisher=Al Jazeera |accessdate=3 July 2013}} As in other days, there were both anti-Morsi and pro-Morsi protests, the latter particularly in Nasr City and near Cairo University. Army tanks were reported to surround two smaller pro-Morsi rallies as the demonstrators vowed to defend the government with their lives.{{cite web|author=Winston Sm1th |url=http://www.dailykos.com/story/2013/07/03/1220929/-Al-Jazeera-Reports-that-Tanks-Ordered-to-Pro-Morsi-Rally |title=Al Jazeera Reports that Tanks Ordered to Pro-Morsi Rally |work=Daily Kos |date=7 March 2013 |accessdate=3 July 2013}} As the 16:35 deadline set by the army approached, the coalition met with the military leaders for emergency talks, with the expectation that the army would issue a statement when the deadline passed. [[Mohamed El-Baradei]], who was chosen to represent the [[National Salvation Front (Egypt)|National Salvation Front]], was also said to have met army chief General [[Abdel Fattah el-Sisi]].{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/07/20137394753443155.html |title=Egypt's Morsi offers consensus government |publisher=Al Jazeera |accessdate=3 July 2013}} On same day just before the deadline approached, Morsi offered to form a consensus government. An army statement read: "The General Command of the Armed Forces is currently meeting with a number of religious, national, political and youth icons...There will be a statement issued from the General Command as soon as they are done." At the same time the Freedom and Justice Party's senior leader, [[Waleed al-Haddad]], said: "We do not go to invitations (meetings) with anyone. We have a president and that is it." At about 17:30 [[Mohammed Zaki]], Leader of Republic Guards, joined Morsi with some of the Republic Guards officers and conducted the arrest. It was reported from Morsi's assistant [[Yahya Hamed]] the flow of conversation took place as Morsi saying "Mohammed (Leader of Republic Guards) you know well you are going to be trailed for that." and Mohammed Zaki replying: "I know, however I had already told them I don't want in, because of my special good relations with the president."{{POV statement|talk=uncorroborated biased statements|date=November 2016}} ==== 3 July military coup ==== On 3 July, General [[Abdel Fattah el-Sisi]], head of the Egyptian Armed Forces, announced that he there would be calling new presidential and Shura Council elections. The coalition appointed Chief Justice [[Adli Mansour|Adly Mansour]] as the interim president and charged him with forming a transitional [[Technocracy|technocratic]] government.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-23173794 |title=Egypt's Shura Council dissolved: Judicial source |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=4 July 2013|accessdate=6 July 2013}} Military vehicles drove throughout Cairo. Morsi was put under house arrest,{{cite web|title=Reports: Morsi under house arrest, |url=http://hotair.com/archives/2013/07/03/report-morsi-under-house-arrest-military-coup-underway-in-egypt/|publisher=HotAir|accessdate=3 July 2013}} and was believed to be at the [[Republican Guard (Egypt)|Republican Guard]] barracks.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/07/20137319828176718.html |title=President Morsi overthrown in Egypt |publisher=Al Jazeera |accessdate=3 July 2013}} According to other sources he was taken to a military base and his travel was restricted.{{cite news|title=Morsi taken from presidential palace to military base |url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2013/07/03/Report-Morsi-taken-from-presidential-palace-to-military-base/UPI-43551372830618/?spt=hs&or=tn|agency=United Press International|accessdate=3 July 2013}} Army troops and tanks were reported to have surrounded key facilities and installations.{{cite web |author=HAMZA HENDAWI and MAGGIE MICHAEL |url=http://talkingpointsmemo.com/news/egyptian-troops-surround-pro-morsi-ralliers-key-facilities.php |title=Egyptian Troops Surround Pro-Morsi Ralliers, Key Facilities |publisher=Talkingpointsmemo.com |date=3 July 2013 |accessdate=3 July 2013 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130703190702/http://talkingpointsmemo.com/news/egyptian-troops-surround-pro-morsi-ralliers-key-facilities.php |archive-date=3 July 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} At noon, the Republican Guard, who had Morsi in their care, left his side to allow Army commandos to take him to an undisclosed Ministry of Defence building. He offered no resistance. General al-Sisi said: "The president's speech last night failed to meet and conform with the demands [of the people, prompting the armed forces to consult] with some of the symbols of the national forces and the youths without excluding anyone. [They agreed on a road map] that includes initial steps that realize the building of a strong and coherent Egyptian society that does not exclude any of its sons and currents and that end the state of conflict and division."{{cite news|last=El |first=Tarek |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-07-03/mursi-proposes-power-sharing-as-egypt-army-deadline-approaches.html |title=Mursi Ousted as Egypt's President; Constitution Suspended |publisher=Bloomberg |accessdate=3 July 2013}} He added the army was standing apart from the political process but was using its vision as the Egyptian people were calling for help and discharged its responsibility.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/07/201373203740167797.html |title=Transcript: Egypt's army statement |publisher=Al Jazeera |accessdate=3 July 2013}} Al-Sisi named former Chief Justice [[Adli Mansour]] as the interim president and added that he would be sworn in on 4 July. The [[Shura Council]] was also dissolved.{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/75668/Egypt/Politics-/Egypts-Shura-Council-dissolved-Judicial-source.aspx |title=Egypt's Shura Council dissolved: Judicial source – Politics – Egypt – Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date=23 April 2013 |accessdate=6 July 2013}} Morsi condemned his removal as a "full coup" by the general. He also urged everyone to "adhere to peacefulness and avoid shedding blood of fellow countrymen."{{cite news|title=Egypt's Army Ousts Morsi, Who Calls It A 'Coup' |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=198226951 |newspaper=NPR |date=4 July 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130707163525/http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=198226951 |archivedate=7 July 2013 |df=dmy }} The Office of Assistant to President of Egypt on Foreign Relations called Morsi's removal a "military coup",{{cite web|title=Morsi advisor: Military coup is under way in Egypt|url=http://www.itv.com/news/update/2013-07-03/morsi-advisor-military-coup-is-under-way-in-egypt/|publisher=ITV|accessdate=3 July 2013}}{{cite web|title=Supporters of Egyptian president say military coup is underway|url=http://worldnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/07/03/19261466-supporters-of-egyptian-president-say-military-coup-is-underway?lite?ocid=twitter|publisher=NBC News|accessdate=3 July 2013}} and said "there is no democracy without the ballot box".Murphy, Dan. "[http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Backchannels/2013/0703/Egypt-s-Muslim-Brotherhood-and-Morsi-have-their-backs-to-the-wall Egypt's Muslim Brotherhood and Morsi have their backs to the wall,"] ''[[Christian Science Monitor]]'', 3 July 2013 The announcement of the removal of Morsi was met with cheers in Tahrir Square.{{cite news|last=Bradley |first=Matt |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887323899704578583191518313964 |title=Morsi Ousted By Egypt Military |work=The Wall Street Journal |accessdate=3 July 2013 |date=4 July 2013}} Anti-Morsi protesters shouted "[[Allahu akbar]]" and "Long live Egypt" and launched fireworks as green laser lights held by those in the crowd lit the sky.{{cite news|title=Army tightens grip as Egypt awaits final move|url=https://news.yahoo.com/army-tightens-grip-egypt-awaits-final-move-180230573.html;_ylt=AwrNUbH0PtVRUQIAwTHQtDMD|accessdate=4 July 2013|work=Yahoo News|date=4 July 2013}} Mohamed el-Baradei says the coup was to rectify the issues of the revolution. The [[Pope of the Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria|Coptic Pope]] [[Tawadros II]], [[Grand Imam of al-Azhar]] [[Ahmed el-Tayeb]], [[Mohamed ElBaradei]]{{cite news|title=Egypt military unveils transitional roadmap|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/75631/Egypt/Politics-/Egypt-military-unveils-transitional-roadmap.aspx|accessdate=3 July 2013|work=Ahram Online|date=3 July 2013}} and some of the youth leaders of [[Tamarod]], [[Mahmoud Badr]] and Mohamed Abdelaziz, spoke in support of the military intervention. The [[al-Nour party]] also commented in saying that the events occurred as they were not heard in their call for dialogue. Party Secretary-General [[Galal Murra]] commented that: "we took this position (on agreeing to the army political road map) and we took these decisions only so we stop the bloodshed of our people."{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/07/201373193715857906.html |title=Egyptians react to Morsi's removal |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=|accessdate=6 July 2013}} Pro-Morsi protesters heard a statement from Morsi, which was published on his Facebook page. He called the move a "coup" and rejected the Armed Forces' statement. The Freedom and Justice Party's Gamal Heshmat said: "There is absolutely no direction towards violence. The Brotherhood are not raised on violence. Their cause is a peaceful one, defending their rights, which is stronger than a "military coup". The army has perpetrated a "shameful coup". We are still in the street, we still don't know if all of the armed forces will accept what Sisi has done."{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/07/03/us-egypt-protests-reaction-idUSBRE9621F720130703?feedType=RSSM |title=Egypt's Brotherhood will not use violence: senior leader |publisher=Reuters |date=3 July 2013|accessdate=6 July 2013 |first=Tom |last=Perry}} A party spokesman said that what started as a military coup was "turning into something much more." The [[National Salvation Front (Egypt)|National Salvation Front]], an alliance of multiple political parties, stated on 4 July that "what Egypt is witnessing now is not a military coup by any standards. It was a necessary decision that the Armed Forces’ leadership took to protect democracy, maintain the country's unity and integrity, restore stability and get back on track towards achieving the goals of the January 25 Revolution."{{cite news|title=Egypt's National Salvation Front: It is not a coup|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/75683/Egypt/Politics-/Egypts-National-Salvation-Front-It-is-not-a-coup.aspx|accessdate=6 July 2013|newspaper=Ahram Online|date=4 July 2013}} ===Arrests=== According to Morsi, he was kidnapped by the [[Egyptian Armed Forces|Armed Forces]] and held at the [[Republican Guard (Egypt)|Republican Guard]] headquarters one day before the army announced his removal, and held there until 5 July 2013, after which he and his aide were forcibly moved to a naval base for the next four months.{{cite news|title=Profile: Morsi claims to be kidnapped|url=http://www.jpost.com/Middle-East/Egypts-Morsi-says-he-was-kidnapped-before-being-removed-by-army-331597|accessdate=11 December 2013|newspaper=The Jerusalem Post |date=13 November 2013}}{{cite news|title=Profile: Morsi claims to be kidnapped |url=http://www.presstv.com/detail/2013/11/14/334588/morsi-says-he-was-kidnapped-before-coup/ |accessdate=11 December 2013 |newspaper=Press TV |date=14 November 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131218092735/http://www.presstv.com/detail/2013/11/14/334588/morsi-says-he-was-kidnapped-before-coup/ |archivedate=18 December 2013 |df=dmy }}{{cite news|last=Georgy|first=Michael|title=Morsi Claims He Was Kidnapped Before Being Removed By Army|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/11/13/morsi-claims-kidnapped_n_4265964.html|publisher=Huffington Post|accessdate=16 March 2014|date=13 November 2013}} His family had stated earlier Morsi was kidnapped on 3 July 2013.{{cite news|title=Profile: Morsi Kidnapped|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/family-of-ousted-egypt-president-mohammed-morsi-accuses-military-of-kidnapping-him/|accessdate=11 December 2013|newspaper=CBC News |date=22 July 2013}} The spokesperson of the [[Egyptian Armed Forces]], [[Colonel]] [[Ahmed Mohammed Ali|Ahmed Ali]] later denied allegations that Morsi was badly treated, saying they had nothing to hide.{{cite news|title=Egypt Army Hiding Morsi In Secret Location, Extreme Measures Taken To Keep Detention Site Hidden |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/07/31/egypt-army-hiding-morsi_n_3685041.html |work=Huffington Post |date=31 July 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131221174056/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/07/31/egypt-army-hiding-morsi_n_3685041.html |archivedate=21 December 2013 |df=dmy}} The [[Egyptian Armed Forces|Egyptian Army]] later gave [[Catherine Ashton]] the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy for the [[European Union]] permission to meet Morsi. Ashton later stated that Morsi was doing well: "Morsi was keeping up with the latest developments in the country through television and newspapers. So we were able to talk about the situation, and we were able to talk about the need to move forward. The people around him do care for him. I looked at the facilities."{{cite news|title=Catherine Ashton Meets With Mohammed Morsi, Says Egypt's Ex-President Doing Well |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/07/30/catherine-ashton-meets-mohammed-morsi_n_3675740.html |work=Huffington Post |date=30 July 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131221174034/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/07/30/catherine-ashton-meets-mohammed-morsi_n_3675740.html |archivedate=21 December 2013 |df=dmy}}{{cite news|title=Ousted Egypt leader Morsi in good health, says EU's Ashton|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-23500117 |work=[[BBC News]] |date=30 July 2013}}{{cite web|title=EU's Catherine Ashton meets with Mohammed Morsi: ‘He is well’|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2013/jul/30/eus-catherine-ashton-meets-mohammed-morsi-he-well/}} Morsi could later meet an [[African Union]] delegation too. [[File:Morsi supporter after mass killings of 27-July-2013.jpg|thumb|Morsi supporter after mass killings in Cairo, 27 July 2013]] The army arrested the former speaker of parliament and the head of [[Freedom and Justice Party (Egypt)|Freedom and Justice Party]] [[Saad El-Katatni]], along with [[Rashad al-Bayoumi]], a Muslim Brotherhood deputy,{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.jpost.com/Breaking-News/Egypt-police-arrest-top-Brotherhood-leaders-318651 |title=Egypt police arrest top Brotherhood leaders |publisher=Jpost.com |date=|accessdate=6 July 2013}} as well as other top leaders of the [[Muslim Brotherhood]].{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/egypt-police-arrest-top-brotherhood-leaders-as-deadly-clashes-leave-at-least-10-dead.aspx?pageID=238&nID=50000&NewsCatID=352 |title=Egypt military confirms it is holding Morsi as deadly clashes leave at least 10 dead |publisher=Hurriyetdailynews.com |date=|accessdate=4 July 2013}} ''Al-Jazeera'' quoted unnamed security officials saying that "more than a dozen" members of the Muslim Brotherhood had been arrested, while ''[[Al-Ahram]]'' reported that the Egyptian police had been ordered to arrest more than 300 members of the Muslim Brotherhood.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/egypt/10158775/Egypts-army-drives-Mohammed-Morsi-from-presidency-and-power-in-dramatic-coup.html |title=Egypt's army drives Mohammed Morsi from presidency and power in dramatic coup |publisher=Telegraph |date=7 April 2013 |accessdate=4 July 2013 |location=London |first=Richard |last=Spencer}} A travel ban was also put on Morsi, the head of his Muslim Brotherhood [[Mohammed Badie]], Badie's deputy [[Khairat El-Shater]], the Muslim Brotherhood's former leader [[Mahdi Akef]], another Muslim Brotherhood figure [[Mohamed Beltagy]], Salafi preacher close to the Muslim Brotherhood [[Safwat Hegazi]] and the leader of the [[al-Wasat Party]] [[Abou Elela Mady]] and his deputy [[Essam Sultan]].{{cite news|author=Abigail Hauslohner|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/world/2013/07/03/egypt_protests_mohammed_morsi_banned_from_travel_military_coup_underway_advisor_says.html |title=Egypt protests: Protesters joyous as army removes Morsi, Morsi rejects 'coup' |work=Toronto Star |accessdate=3 July 2013 |date=3 July 2013}} Badie and Akef were arrested for "incitement to murder." Following Morsi's ouster, pro-Morsi supporters still gathered in Cairo said that they would undo the "coup" and continued their allegiance to Morsi saying that they would "defend the integrity of the ballot box." Amidst threats of violence, ''[[Al Jazeera English]]'' reported the death of four people from a Muslim Brotherhood stronghold near the Libyan border.{{Citation needed|date=July 2013}} In December 2013, Morsi as well as high-echelon Muslim Brotherhood leaders were charged with "terrorism and plotting with foreign militants against Egypt" while the Muslim brotherhood was officially classified as a terrorist group.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/12/25/us-egypt-explosion-brotherhood-idUSBRE9BO08H20131225|newspaper=Reuters|date=25 Dec 2013|author=Shadia Nasralla|quote=Since Mursi's overthrow, the state has killed hundreds of his supporters in the streets and arrested thousands more. Mursi and other top Brotherhood leaders were last week charged with terrorism and plotting with foreign militants against Egypt.|title=Egypt designates Muslim Brotherhood as terrorist group}}{{cite news|title=Egypt sets date for presidential election|url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/egypt-sets-date-for-presidential-election-20140331-zqosp.html|newspaper=Sydney Morning Herald|date=31 March 2014|author=Shadia Nasralla}} By May 2014, approximately 16,000 people, mostly Brotherhood members or supporters, have been imprisoned since the coup.[https://www.economist.com/news/middle-east-and-africa/21601577-mass-death-sentences-may-not-be-carried-out-horrify-all-same-hang-them Hang them all? Mass death sentences may not be carried out, but horrify all the same], economist.com. ===Media restrictions and violence against journalists=== Police and military forces made statements against four television channels and took them off the air. [[Misr 25]], a channel owned by the Muslim Brotherhood, was shut down and officials said that journalists working for the channel were arrested.{{cite web|author=Gregg Carlstrom |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/07/20137412240752156.html |title=Despondent scenes at pro-Morsi rally |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=|accessdate=4 July 2013}} The [[Al Hafez]] and [[Al Nas]] channels were shut down as well. A few hours later, ''[[Al Jazeera]]'''s ''[[Mubasher Misr]]'', which had been criticised for its alleged pro-Morsi slant, was also taken off the air, its offices raided and its employees detained.{{cite news|title=Egyptian security cracks down on Al-Jazeera Mubasher Misr|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/75646/Egypt/Politics-/Egyptian-security-cracks-down-on-AlJazeera-Mubashe.aspx|accessdate=4 July 2013|newspaper=Al Ahram|date=4 July 2013}} Five staff were arrested, including managing director Ayman Gaballah, who was still in custody after the others were released. It was also prevented from broadcasting a pro-Morsi rally in northern Cairo. ''[[Associated Press Television News]]'' was ordered not to provide ''Al Jazeera'' with footage of protests in the country or with any filming equipment, while the ''[[Cairo News Company]]'' was warned against providing broadcasting equipment. Al Jazeera Media Network's acting Director General Mostafa Souag condemned the move, saying "regardless of political views, the Egyptian people expect media freedoms to be respected and upheld. Media offices should not be subject to raids and intimidation. Journalists should not be detained for doing their jobs."{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/07/201374223725841263.html |title=Groups condemn raids on Egypt TV channels |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=|accessdate=6 July 2013}} The [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] (CPJ) reported that two journalists and one student were killed while covering Egyptian unrest in the two weeks leading up to 8 July 2013.{{cite web|title=Egyptian press under fire after Morsi's ouster|url=http://cpj.org/2013/07/egyptian-journalist-killed-press-targeted-after-mo.php|publisher=Committee to Protect Journalists|accessdate=10 July 2013|date=8 July 2013}} According to CPJ research, before those deaths only four journalists had been killed in Egypt since 1992. One of the journalists killed while documenting the 2013 clashes was 26-year-old photographer Ahmed Assem el-Senousy, also known as Ahmed Samir Assem.{{cite web|last=Bennett|first=Dashiell|title=Photographer May Have Captured His Own Death During Egypt Protests|url=http://www.theatlanticwire.com/global/2013/07/egyptian-photographer-captured-his-own-death/67013/|publisher=The Atlantic Wire|accessdate=10 July 2013|date=10 July 2013}}{{cite news|last=Bennett-Smith|first=Meredith|title=Ahmed Assem El-Senousy, Egyptian Photographer, Films Own Death By Egyptian Sniper?|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/07/10/ahmed-assem-el-senousy-photographer-death-sniper-egypt-video_n_3573705.html|publisher=The Huffington Post|accessdate=10 July 2013|date=10 July 2013}} The photographer was shot by a sniper after he recorded security forces firing on protestors. According to media reports, el-Senousy may have captured his own death on film. A video clip posted on his Facebook page shows a sniper firing on crowds before turning toward the camera, at which point the clip abruptly ends. While reporting for the [[BBC News|BBC]], journalist [[Jeremy Bowen]] was hit in the head with birdshot fired by Egyptian security forces on 5 July. ==Aftermath== [[File:Damietta protests.jpg|thumb|Supporters of the ousted President Morsi demonstrate in [[Damietta]] on 5 July 2013.]] On 4 July, violence continued with over 100 people wounded and at least two deaths, believed to be that of children. The Muslim Brotherhood's spokesman called for "strictly peaceful" protests to defy the "military coup".{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/article/1695591.html |title=Egypt Braces for New Round of Protests |publisher=Voanews.com |date=|accessdate=6 July 2013}} Other Islamist groups threatened armed retaliation, while the police arrested four armed men on 5 July over claims that they had planned a reprisal attack, according to state-run ''[[Al-Ahram]]''. The Supreme Council of the Armed Forces added that it would protect all groups from revenge attacks and that Egyptian values "do not allow for gloating." Protests after [[Friday prayers]] were called by Morsi supporters, now in opposition, and termed "Rejection Friday." That morning, troops [[2013 Republican Guard headquarters clashes|opened fire killing at least 51 pro-Morsi protesters]] at the Republican Guard headquarters in which Morsi was believed to be held.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-23202096|publisher=BBC News|title=Egypt troops kill pro-Morsi marchers|date=6 July 2013}} According to some witnesses, the military opened fire without provocation towards the end of morning prayers, immediately using live ammunition and shooting to kill.[[New York Times]], 8 July 2013, [https://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/09/world/middleeast/egypt.html?pagewanted=2&_r=0&hp Army Kills 51, Deepening Crisis in Egypt]{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/story/1111961/egypt-coup-three-killed-in-cairo-gun-battle|title=Egypt Coup: Three Killed In Cairo Gun Battle|publisher=Sky News|date=6 July 2013}} At least 51 Morsi supporters were killed and 435 were injured. Though the Egyptian Army denied firing at the protesters, ''[[BBC News]]'' reporter [[Jeremy Bowen]] said he saw soldiers firing on protesters.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-23202096 |title=Egypt unrest: Morsi marchers die as army fires |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=1 January 1970 |accessdate=6 July 2013}} In [[Qena]], security forces opened fire on protesters trying to storm a security building, injuring two of them. Shots were also fired in Alexandria. This occurred as tens of thousands of Egyptians took to the street to condemn the coup and support Morsi.{{cite news|author=|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/world/2013/07/05/egypt_uprising_tens_of_thousands_of_morsi_supporters_take_to_streets.html |title=Egypt uprising: Tens of thousands of Morsi supporters take to streets |publisher=Thestar.com |date=5 July 2013|accessdate=6 July 2013 |location=Toronto}} Despite claiming to respect all sides, the military also issued a statement warning Islamists who planned on protesting. Tamarod, which had organised anti-Morsi protests, called for protests to "protect the revolution." During the night pro and anti-Morsi demonstrators clashed over the [[6th October Bridge]]; at least two people were killed and more than 70 people were injured, according to state television, who quoted medical personnel at a makeshift hospital in the square. At least three deaths were that of Morsi supporters during the march towards the military barracks after the Friday prayer in Cairo.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/07/201375183931989733.html |title=Fierce fighting in Cairo as protests continue |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=|accessdate=6 July 2013}} In all, through the night of rioting, throughout the country 30 people were killed. Pro-Morsi demonstrators continued to call for protests.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/07/2013767313227438.html |title=Egypt tense after night-long clashes |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=|accessdate=6 July 2013}} Protesters continued to demand the reinstatement of Morsi throughout the weekend, some of which were violent protests.[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/07/20137614383778288.html Morsi supporters mass in Cairo's Nasr City – Middle East]. Al Jazeera English. Retrieved on 14 August 2013. Palestinian officials in [[Gaza Strip|Gaza]] also said that the Egyptian Armed Forces had shut the [[Rafah border crossing]] and that only certain people, such as patients and students, would be allowed through. Egyptian Intelligence Service official Nader al-Asar telephoned Palestinian [[Prime Minister of the Gaza Strip|Prime Minister in Gaza]] [[Ismail Haniyeh]] on the afternoon of 5 July and Haniyeh briefed him about the humanitarian crisis in Gaza as a result of the restrictions on tunnels and the Rafah crossing. Al-Asar promised to seek remedies on the situation{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.middleeastmonitor.com/news/middle-east/6478-egyptian-army-demands-closure-of-rafah-crossing#sthash.4gBn1njS.dpuf|title=Egyptian army demands closure of Rafah Crossing|publisher=Middleeastmonitor.com|date=|accessdate=6 July 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927151622/http://www.middleeastmonitor.com/news/middle-east/6478-egyptian-army-demands-closure-of-rafah-crossing#sthash.4gBn1njS.dpuf#sthash.4gBn1njS.dpuf|archive-date=27 September 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} After dawn prayers on 8 July [[2013 Republican Guard headquarters clashes|clashes erupted]] between pro-Morsi protesters and the army at the Republican Guard compound. According to the army, "terrorists" tried to storm the compound and one officer and 42 other people were injured.{{cite news|title=At least 42 killed in Egypt, Islamists call for uprising|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/07/08/us-egypt-protests-idUSBRE95Q0NO20130708|accessdate=8 July 2013|newspaper=Reuters|date=8 July 2013}} On the other hand, the Muslim Brotherhood said that 42 of its supporters were killed and over 300 were injured after shootings that followed the police storming their peaceful sit-in demanding the reinstatement of Morsi. MP [[Mohamed Beltagy]] described the incident as a "massacre" during dawn prayers.[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/07/20137821320932698.html Massacre in Cairo deepens Egypt crisis – Middle East]. Al Jazeera English. Retrieved on 14 August 2013. After the incident, the Freedom and Justice Party, called for "the international community and international groups and all the free people of the world [to] intervene to stop further massacres [...] and prevent a new Syria in the Arab world."[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/07/20137872812532255.html Muslim Brotherhood calls for Egypt uprising – Middle East]. Al Jazeera English. Retrieved on 14 August 2013. The Nour party said it would suspend taking part in the political process as a response to the deadly clashes. And Ahmed el-Hawary, a founding member of the [[Al-Dustour (Egypt)|al-Dustour]] party and a member of 30 June front, said: "We cannot blame the Muslim Brotherhood without blaming the army. They are both held accountable for this catastrophe...The Brotherhood is playing victims to gain international sympathy yet losing whatever is left of the sympathy at home. A speedy formation of the new cabinet is essential at this point, and although consensus is critical. Egypt must not be the hostage of a concurrence based on non-pertinent arguments."[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/07/20137884857657920.html Reactions to Cairo shootings – Middle East]. Al Jazeera English. Retrieved on 14 August 2013. At the same time, Morsi supporters were said by the military of having forced two soldiers, Samir Abdallah Ali and Azzam Hazem Ali, to make pro-Morsi statements on a loudspeaker and that one of them was "severely beaten up" and filmed while making the statements. However, an army official later said that they had "managed to escape their captors."[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/07/20137891839289850.html Seized Egyptian soldiers escape – Middle East]. Al Jazeera English. Retrieved on 14 August 2013. On 8 July, following reports that many [[Foreign rebel fighters in the Syrian civil war|fighters in Syria]] were returning in support of the Muslim Brotherhood, Egypt slapped restrictions on Syrians entering the country and required them to obtain visas before entering the country.[https://archive.is/20130710024646/http://www.sfgate.com/news/world/article/Syria-s-ruling-party-elects-new-command-amid-war-4651842.php ] An arrest warrant was issued against Mohamed Badie also as the party refused to join a transitional government.[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/07/2013710132614672647.html Egypt orders arrest of Brotherhood leader – Middle East]. Al Jazeera English. Retrieved on 14 August 2013. The Investigative Reporting Program at the [[University of California at Berkeley]] showed that a State Department programme ostensible to support democracy provided funds to activists and politicians for fomenting unrest in Egypt after the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak in February 2011.[http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2013/07/2013710113522489801.html Exclusive: US bankrolled anti-Morsi activists – Features]. Al Jazeera English. Retrieved on 14 August 2013. The Muslim Brotherhood vowed to continue its resistance to the military's ouster of Morsi. In a statement it disavowed itself from an assassination attempt against a senior army commander in the Sinai Peninsula on 10 July and said it adheres to peaceful measures. The statement also read: "We will continue our peaceful resistance to the bloody military coup against constitutional legitimacy. We trust that the peaceful and popular will of the people shall triumph over force and oppression."[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/07/201371113239887638.html Egypt's Brotherhood vows to keep defying coup – Middle East]. Al Jazeera English. Retrieved on 14 August 2013. The public prosecutor{{who|date=July 2013}} issued a freeze on the assets of the Muslim Brotherhood's leaders, as well as other supporters pending investigations in ongoing cases related to events in al-Mokatam, al-Nahda square and the Republican Guards Club. This would affect Mohamed Badie, Khairat al-Shater, Mohamed Ezat, Mahi Ekef, Saed ElKatatni, Essam ElErian, Mohamed ElBeltagy and the Muslim Brotherhood's allies, including Essam Sultan, Assem Abdul Majed, Safwat Hegazy and Hazem Abu Ismail, will also be affected by the freeze.[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/07/2013714145744713127.html Egypt freezes Muslim Brotherhood funds – Middle East]. Al Jazeera English. Retrieved on 14 August 2013. In addition to continuing daily protests, the Muslim Brotherhood called for more protests after Friday prayers on 19 July.[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/07/201371817824261205.html Egypt's Brotherhood promises more protests – Middle East]. Al Jazeera English. Retrieved on 14 August 2013. The protests were held in Cairo and Alexandria with two formations of fighter jets flying over both cities after noon prayers ended and some military helicopters flew low over roof tops in Cairo. Amongst the tens of thousands of protesters present, they chanted "Islamic, Islamic" calling for an Islamic state.[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/07/2013719105846819271.html Egypt's deadly political stalemate drags on – Middle East]. Al Jazeera English. Retrieved on 14 August 2013. The protests again turned violent and fatal in Cairo and [[Qalyoub]] on 22 July.[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/07/201372216452414482.html Attacks in Egypt lift death toll amid turmoil – Middle East]. Al Jazeera English. Retrieved on 14 August 2013. Morsi's family also held a press conference in Cairo in which his children accused the military of kidnapping him, as well as announcing local and international legal measures they had initiated against General Abdul Fatah al-Sisi.[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/07/2013722113223508246.html Family accuses Egypt army of kidnapping Morsi – Middle East]. Al Jazeera English. Retrieved on 14 August 2013. In mid-August, the violence against Islamists by the army escalated further, with at least hundreds killed, and the government declaring a month-long nighttime curfew.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-23700663|title=Egypt declares national emergency|date=14 August 2013|publisher=BBC News}}{{cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/news/leaders/21583702-generals-killing-spree-reckless-denial-lessons-arab-spring-battle|title=Egypt's bloodbath: The battle for Egypt|date=17 August 2013|publisher=The Economist}} Following the mid-August incidents and the imposition of a state of emergency, security forces targeted the Brotherhood and its allies with a wave of arrests of leaders and senior members. ===14 August crackdown=== {{main article|August 2013 Rabaa massacre}} [[File:Dead bodies in RABIA Massacre (3).jpg|thumb|180px|Bodies of pro-Morsi Muslim Brotherhood members]] On 14 August 2013, Egyptian security forces raided two camps of protesters in Cairo: one at al-Nahda Square and a larger one at Rabaa al-Adawiya Mosque. The two sites had been occupied by supporters of ousted President Mohamed Morsi, who was removed from office by the military after mass street protests against him. The camps were raided after initiatives to end the six-week sit-ins failed and as a result of the raids the camps were cleared out within hours. The Interior Minister Mohamed Ibrahim announced that police used water hoses to disperse the campers. Yet, all videos and photos from the scenes of the raids never showed water or hoses. Tents and bodies were on fire, and the main mosque of [[Rabaa al-Adawiya mosque|Rabaa Al-Adawiya]] was burned with hundreds of unidentified bodies.{{cite book|last=El-Hewie|first=Mohamed F|title=Islam Facts and Fiction And The Fight For Egypt|year=2013|publisher=Shaymaa Publishing|location=USA|isbn=1493577530|page=246|url=https://www.amazon.com/Islam-Facts-Fiction-Fight-Egypt/dp/1493577530/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1383300968&sr=1-1&keywords=Islam+Facts+and+Fiction+And+The+Fight+For+Egypt}} According to the Egyptian Health Ministry, 638 people were killed on 14 August, of which 595 were civilians and 43 police officers, with at least 3,994 injured. However, the Muslim brotherhood and National Coalition for Supporting Legitimacy (NCSL) put the number of deaths from the Rabaa al-Adawiya Mosque sit-in alone at some 2,600. Violent retaliation followed in several cities across the country. The interim government declared a month-long state of emergency in response and curfews were instituted in many areas. The total casualty count made 14 August the deadliest day since the 2011 Egyptian revolution which toppled Morsi's predecessor Hosni Mubarak. The clashes between the police and some armed protestors were widely denounced by world leaders, with the exception of Gulf Arab states: the U.A.E., Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, and potential GCC member Jordan.
